entry.title: Automating Training Assignments Using Integer Custom Fields
entry.content:
Background

For years, customers requested enhancements to assign training dynamically after hire or after completing another item. Below are some key requests:

Enhancement Requests

  • Allow training to be assigned X days after hire date
  • Automatic assignment after X days of completing Item A
  • Assign training via Assignment Profile X days after hire date

New Feature in 2H 2025

SAP introduced Integer and Decimal data types for custom fields in the User entity. This enables operators like Less Than or Equal To, Greater Than or Equal To, and Between for numeric criteria in Assignment Profiles.

Though this is not a perfect solution we can utilize for our requirement.

Step-by-Step Implementation

We will walk through an example: Assign onboarding course 15 days after joining for hires after 1st Jan 2025.

Configuration in LMS

Creating References

  • Create custom fields: Navigate to Learning Administration > System Administration > Custom Fields > User. Select data type as Integer and assign a unique field number (e.g., 170). 
  • Add new and you can select ‚Äúdata type‚Äù as Integer
  • For field number you can put any number except standard custom field numbers(10,20‚Ä¶150)
  • In this example I have used 170 ,you can enter any number you like.

Creating Integer Custom Field

Adding Configuration

  • Once created, you need to add the reference in connector configuration file so that your user connector will pick it up
  • To do that go to Learning Administration>System Administration>Configuration >System Configuration
    in this select Connector and add following line at bottom

Sample file

Sfuser.field.customcolumn.<your_column_number>=<your_column_name_in_connector_file>

For example I have created 2 columns below

#No of Years after hiring
Sfuser.field.customcolumn.160=YOE

#No of Day after hiring
Sfuser.field.customcolumn.170=DAH

If you do not want to touch your user data file or your user data file is coming from provisioning then you can use user extended data file
for that just modify the formula like this.

Sfuser.extendeduser.field.customcolumn.<your_column_number>=<your_column_name_in_connector_file>

Example -

Sfuser.extendeduser.field.customcolumn.160=YOE
Sfuser.extendeduser.field.customcolumn.170=DAH

Now the work in LMS is done for User connector part

Setting up Integration

If you do not have integration center job  for user connector  then you can go through following guide - SuccessFactors: Goodbye Provisioning Jobs Part 1 | Using Integration Center (IC) for synchronizing user data from Foundation to LMS via SF - User Connector 
I strongly recommend to move from Provisioning to IC job for User Connector for easy to access ,configure and debug.

Now you have Integration center job, you have to create new column for ‚ÄúDays After Hiring‚Äù
select Numeric value in Field Data Type
use following screenshot for reference


Days after hiring calculation

You can also add ‚ÄúYears after Hiring‚Äù


Years after hiring calculation

User the above settings for creating new Numeric columns and run/schedule your IC job

If you do not want to use user data file then you can use user extended data file
sample file you can see here(use the same blog listed above to create the file)
I have attached sample file for your reference

make sure you have used userid column as ^UserId
you can refer the IC job here

Years after hiring calculation

You are done with IC job, Sync this file using User Connector SF and head to Assignment Profile

creating Assignment Profiles

Due to new data type we have new operators specifically for Numerical values‚Äì ‚ÄúLess Than or Equal to‚Äù, ‚ÄúGreater Than or Equal to‚Äù and ‚ÄúBetween‚Äù

New operators for Assignment Profile

Your Requirement ‚Äì any user joined after 1st Jan 2025 ,should get assigned onboarding course after 15th day from Joining.

In Assignment Profile you can create the rule as follows

days rule

Similarly if you want to Assign based on Years of Experience then you can use this

years rule

Also you can use this with JOB Grades where you can use between feature to segregate the grades

between rule

This will eliminate manually selecting each job grade to add into the criteria and give you dynamic option.
I highly encourage to transform your Grades to Numeric values using lookup table in IC so that you can use it as Numeric values (example M1 =1,M2 = 2 etc)

Future cases

Similar to this if you are feeling motivated and adventurous then you can create PRD report which has an user and item completion date and calculation from date of completion

send this data to EC using MDF and use it to extract back to User connector, you have to create this for multiple items and use it to assign courses After completion/assignment of Item A > automatic assignment after X days of Item B

sample report data
userid,itemid,completiondate,today-completiondate
10001,abc123,10-11-2025,5


you can comment on the blog I can consult for the setting up any custom requirement for another item assignment after certain days of first item completion

References:

SuccessFactors: Goodbye Provisioning Jobs Part 1 | Using Integration Center (IC) for synchronizing user data from Foundation to LMS via SF - User Connector 

SuccessFactors: Goodbye Provisioning Jobs Part 2 | Using Integration Center (IC) to import User data from sFTP into Foundation

Support for Integer and Decimal Custom Fields for User Entity 

2571171 - How to create a year calculation field in Integration Center

2594749 - How to use Value Lookup Table in Integration Center

entry.title: Extensibility in Supply Protection
entry.content:
Supply protection operates on some fundamental principles. A demand can match a time bucket, but it can't match different buckets within one protection group. Another core principle is that a matching demand only consumes the protection of the time bucket it matches. If there's no remaining protection for this bucket, the consumption is still recorded for this time bucket. In this case, the remaining protection is zero, not negative. 

Sometimes, customers prefer more flexibility. 

An alternative could be to shift consumption to a time bucket with remaining protection. If the protection of a time bucket is fully consumed, a matching demand should first consume protection of the previous or next time bucket instead of exceeding the protection of the current bucket. 

Another, more specific alternative could be a change for the privileged check quantity if supply protection is set to Restriction outside planned protection. With this setting, a demand has low restriction if protection is remaining for the matching time bucket. If there is no protection remaining, the restriction is quite high.  

Some customers like to be even more flexible. For example, they might want to use the quantity from the next time bucket, the aggregation of all time buckets in the group, or just a defined quantity as the privileged check quantity, instead of the quantity of a single time bucket.  

All these use cases are supported with the help of the available Business Add-Ins (BAdIs). 

  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Redistribution of Consumption (OP 2023 FPS0) 
    (ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection ‚Äì Removal of Restriction Groups (OP2023 FPS0) 
    (ATP_SUP_REMOVAL_RSTRCN_GROUPS) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Remove Restriction Groups Inside Privileged Check Quantity (OP2023 FPS2) 
    (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_IN) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Remove Restriction Groups Outside Privileged Check Quantity (OP2023 FPS2) 
    (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_OUT) 
  • BAdI: ATP Supply Protection - Change of Remaining Protection of Matching Groups (OP2023 FPS2) 
    (ATP_SUP_CHANGE_GRPS_RMNG_PROT) 

Let‚Äôs take a look at the options the different BAdIs provide: 

Redistribution of Consumption (ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN) 

By default, the consumption of protection is assigned only to the matching time bucket and reduces the remaining protection. With the help of the BAdI to redistribute the consumption, it is also possible to write consumptions in other time buckets of the matching protection group. 

One use case is to only write consumptions in the matching time bucket if there is still a remaining protection. If all the protection is consumed, the next consumption should be assigned to another time bucket like the previous or the next time bucket. 


Illustration: Matching Sales Order


Illustration: Distribution of protection across different time buckets with BAdI ATP_SUP_REDISTRIBUTE_CNSMPN 

Removal of Restriction Groups (ATP_SUP_REMOVAL_RSTRCN_GROUPS) 

Higher or equally prioritized protection groups of the matching supply protection object are treated as restriction. Here, the BAdI ‚ÄúRemoval of Restriction Groups‚Äù can change the restrictions. It‚Äôs possible to ignore any other protection group of the matching supply protection object. With this a matching demand is less restricted and the likelihood of getting a confirmation for a request increases. 

For sure, the reliability of the protection in total is reduced if the restriction is not that strict. 

Illustration: Removal of Restrictions

Remove Restriction Groups Inside Privileged Check Quantity (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_IN) 

The restriction type ‚ÄúRestriction outside planned protection‚Äù is a bit more complex as there are potentially two different checks for the availability. If you are not familiar with the restriction type ‚ÄúRestriction outside planned protection‚Äù you should read the related community blog. 
One of the principles is as follows: If the requested quantity is below the remaining protection of the matching time bucket, the restriction is low. For requested quantities which exceed the remaining protection of the matching time bucket the restriction is high. 

Illustration: Removal of Restrictions ‚ÄùInside Privileged Check Quantity‚Äù

In the illustration, parallel restrictions with the same priority also exist. Equal and higher prioritized protections are considered as restrictions for the check ‚Äúinside the privileged check quantity‚Äù. With the BAdI ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_IN it is possible to remove these restrictions. 

Remove Restriction Groups Outside Privileged Check Quantity (ATP_SUP_RMVL_RSTR_GRPS_U2P_OUT) 

For demands exceeding the remaining protection of the matching time bucket, the restriction might be high, as also lower prioritized protections are considered as restriction. This is a basic principle of the restriction type ‚ÄúRestriction outside planned protection‚Äù. However, for this kind of restrictions a BAdI exists to remove protection groups. If there are many vertical protection groups, it might be interesting to not be restricted by all the groups of lower priority, but just by the groups which are one or two levels below. 

Using the BAdIs to remove restrictions is something every customer should think about very carefully. One setting is possible, but it would never make sense. It would be wrong to have a demand facing a lower restriction if it is already outside of the own protection compared to the restrictions of the first check within the own protection. 


Illustration: Removal of Restrictions ‚ÄùOutside Privileged Check Quantity‚Äù 

Change of Remaining Protection of Matching Groups 
(ATP_SUP_CHANGE_GRPS_RMNG_PROT) 

With the BAdI ‚ÄúChange of Remaining Protection of Matching Groups‚Äù it is possible to change the quantity we also sometimes call the ‚ÄúInplan-Quantity‚Äù or the ‚Äúprivileged Quantity‚Äù. This is the quantity which is checked for the first check for the restriction type ‚ÄúRestriction outside planned Protection‚Äù. Sometime customers want to have more flexibility here as well. One simple use case is as follows ... 
If there are monthly time buckets the remaining protection might be quite low at the end of the month as the protection is already consumed. If the request matched the next time bucket, the confirmed quantities would be higher again. Therefore, some customers want to consider the protected quantities of the following or previous time bucket as an additional quantity for the first check. In this case they also want to redistribute the consumption afterwards again, so that consumptions exceeding the own planned protections are only stored at a time bucket, if the remaining protection of the surrounding time buckets is already expired.  


Illustration: With the BAdI ATP_SUP_CHANGE_GRPS_RMNG_PROT quantities of additional time buckets are considered as ‚ÄùPrivileged Check Quantity‚Äù

There are different options to change the logic of Supply Protection and customer can use the application more flexible. However, every change of the logic in standard has an impact, and the BAdIs should be used very carefully. 

Links 

SAP Help: App Extensibility: Manage Supply Protection (Key User)

entry.title: Re: Why are Consumption Mode and Consumption Period field...
entry.content:
Dear @Aght,


Yes, what you‚Äôre seeing is expected / standard design in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition today. The consumption-related fields are simply not part of the UI scope of ‚ÄúManage Product Master Data‚Äù (F1602), so no role, SSCUI trick will make them appear.

Yes. SAP explicitly documents that Manage Product Master Data does not show all product master fields:

  • SAP Note: 3644447 ‚Äì Missing field in Manage Product Master Data app

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3644447

It also clarifies that the app does not provide all fields that are available in Change Material / Create Material and vice versa.

  • There is a very similar case for Mixed MRP: the field is not available in Manage Product Master Data and SAP calls this a limitation of the current version of the app‚Äôs UI, i.e. not an authorization or config issue.

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/where-is-mixed-mrp-located-in-the-public-cloud-version-of-the-fiori-app/qaq-p/14254909

So your observation that consumption mode/period and other MRP3 details are visible in MM02 but not in F1602 matches exactly what SAP describes as standard behavior.

SAP split responsibilities between the apps:

  • Manage Product Master Data (F1602) is a simplified, role-based product master app focusing on the most commonly used fields for day-to-day product maintenance. It was never intended to be a 1:1 replacement of every MM02 field.
  • Create/Change Material (MM01/MM02) (expert/GUI apps) remain the full-blown maintenance tools for all legacy and expert fields including niche MRP and demand-management settings such as:
    • Consumption Mode
    • Forward/Backward Consumption Period
    • MRP-Group-related consumption parameters
    • Other detailed MRP3 controls

SAP also confirms in the Best Practice scripts that some required MRP3 fields (including consumption settings) are currently not available in F1602 and explicitly tell you to use the classic material apps instead. In the scope item 2T7 (Create Product Master of Type Configurable Material), there‚Äôs a note in the steps for Manage Product Master Data saying:

The required fields are currently unavailable for this application. Use Option 1 (Create Material (MM01)).

So it‚Äôs not that your system is misconfigured ‚Äì SAP has simply not exposed those MRP3 consumption fields in the F1602 UI at all.

There isn‚Äôt a fine-grained, per-field list (‚Äúthese exact MRP fields are excluded‚Äù), but you have:

  • Product Master Apps ‚Äì Feature Comparison
    SAP Help has a ‚ÄúFeature Comparison for Apps in Product Master‚Äù which explains that the various product master apps (Manage Product Master Data, Create Material, Change Material, etc.) have different feature scopes and are not equivalent.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f86dc2eb1f8b48c880a7607213104b27/4caca3c4d6934e6b8ba855eb61de06e2.html

  • Manage Product Master Data ‚Äì App documentation
    The app documentation repeatedly states you can ‚Äúsearch, display, edit, create, copy master data‚Äù but does not claim it covers all fields from the material master.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f86dc2eb1f8b48c880a7607213104b27/0483875792f25c08e10000000a441470.html

  • Best Practice process docs (2T7, BNT)
    They show MRP3 consumption parameters in procedure steps, but where F1602 cannot support them, a specific note tells you to switch to Create/Change Material.

 

Together with KBA 3644447, that‚Äôs effectively SAP‚Äôs documentation that:

‚ÄúSome product master fields (including certain MRP fields) are intentionally not supported in F1602.‚Äù

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: manual creation of Task outside of ChaRM
entry.content:
According to KBA 2203520 ‚Äî How to restrict users to create Transport Requests using ChaRM onlyÔºö

Please check whether the project assignment is set as mandatory for a Transport Request in the managed system. This can be set either from Solution Manager system or into Managed system directly.

If users still can create Transport Requests manually from managed system without using ChaRM, then remove authorization to create Transport requests in each system from all users (except ChaRM / Service connections). In this way, users won't be able to create Transport Requests from outside the Task list but can still work as normal in ChaRM and create Transport Requests from the Change Document itself as this uses RFC users.
So, remove activity 01 (create) from: 
Object: S_TRANSPRT
Activity: 01 - Create
Request Type: CUST     Customizing Requests & DTRA     Workbench Requests

entry.title: Archiving Customers: transactional Data not deleted
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

I am trying to archive customer in our ECC system. We only have FI Documents (Object FI_DOCUMNT) and transactional Data (FI_TF_DEB) as prerequisite for customer. 

I archived & deleted FI documents. Good. 

I could only archive transactional data before 2024 (current year 2025). SARA says you cannot archive transactional data from this year and last year. so the customer still has an entry in KNC1 (Transactional data) even though it has 0 Balance. 

so the question is, is it wrong to carry forward balances with 0 amount (meaning customer didnt have any postings that year) every year.  or is the issue with SARA (Archiving) that says, there shouldnt exists any entry in KNC1. 

and why is there no mention of this anywhere in the internet, feels like I am missing something basic here. 

thanks, 

Regards,

entry.title: SAP Service & Asset Manager 2505 ‚Äì Document Duplication After Sync
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am facing an issue in SAP Service & Asset Manager (SSAM) 2505 related to document attachments. This happens in both the Work Order Details screen and the Work Order Operation Details screen.

Issue Description:
In the Documents section, when I add a photo (or any other document), the upload works correctly. After adding the document, I can edit it and save it without any issue.

However, once I perform a Sync, something unexpected happens:

The document successfully appears in the backend  ‚Üí so the upload is working.

The sync completes without errors.

But after the sync, the same document appears duplicated in the mobile app.

The duplicated document shows the sync icon (sync wheel indicator) on the left side, even though the original document is already synced. attached image file (Attached image: img.jpg)

After syncing, a single duplicate of the document appears ‚Äî subsequent syncs do not create additional duplicates.

Please note that -> I am using a created Android client with the following version:
"AppVersion": "2505.0.1"

Has anyone experienced this duplication behavior in SSAM 2505?
Is there any known fix, metadata adjustment, or rule modification required to prevent from this issue?

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated.

Best Regards

Divan Wellalage

entry.title: Why iFlow Replicate Sales Order and Sales Quote from SAP S4HANA only allows iDocs
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am currently working on a standard integration between SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 for the replication of Sales Orders ‚Äì from S/4 to Sales Cloud v2.

I have come across something that seems completely inconsistent, and I cannot explain it:

1. In DRFIMG, the only outbound implementation for Sales Orders is 114_1 (Webservice)

In DRFIMG ‚Üí Define Outbound Implementations, the object SalesOrder only offers the Webservice outbound implementation 114_1.
There is no IDoc outbound option available.

2. The SAP standard iFlow for Sales Cloud v2, however, expects an IDoc structure

In the SAP Integration Suite package ‚ÄúSAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP S/4HANA‚Äù, the sender adapter for the iFlow ‚ÄúReplicate Sales Order and Sales Quote from SAP S/4HANA‚Äù must be configured as IDoc.
The iFlow clearly expects an IDoc XML payload.

If you send SOAP/Webservice messages instead, errors occur such as:

  • HTTP 401

  • unsupported xstream in SRT_MONI

Which makes sense, because the iFlow internally seems to process IDoc payloads only, not SOAP.

My question to the community:

How does this fit together?

  • Is this an intentional design?

  • Why is the iFlow still using IDoc structures here?

  • If DRFIMG does not provide an IDoc outbound implementation, how is this integration supposed to work?

  • What are the recommended options or best practices?

  • Any guidance or tips from someone who has implemented this scenario successfully would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Re: SAP Document AI Made Simple: A Functional Analyst‚Äôs Plug-and-Play Guide
entry.content:
Hi avikjuoss94

Thanks for this walk-thru. It is really very good and thorough...

...but (and now I hope I don't spoil your weekend or anything) I have gone thru this at least 5-6 times and I have thought of writing a similar guide. The problem is that SAP is changing BTP, Document AI, Free-Tier and anything else so fast that every time I have gone thru this setup, the path to the goal has been different and none of my setups went exactly like what you describe.

So be prepared - tomorrow you will have to re-write it to be up to date.

The Document AI itself is also changing very fast, but I think the documentation is following the changes very well. When I saw the documentation first time it was 16 pages and today it is 529 pages. It seems they release new changes and documentation at least once a month. SAP Document AI Documentation  

So yes, this is very interesting but fully understanding is currently as easy as trying to nail jelly to a wall.

entry.title: Re: Maintenance task list with external services in S/4HA...
entry.content:
Hello @S0027154449 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some references for more details.

Currency Handling, Understanding Currency Scaling

Blog: Change of NumberFormat Behavior for Currencies with UI5 version 1.130

To summarise, in public cloud, MM-Service procurement internally uses 2-decimal commercial calculations while the Peso is a zero-decimal currency. Because of this, the system automatically multiplies all service prices by 100, which is why your task list prices appear amplified when copied into a maintenance order. Therefore, the behaviour you experienced is not caused by PM or Taks List configuration.

I recommend you use service materials; this will avoid decimal scaling completely. If N/E must be used, then enter prices divided by 100 in the task list so that final COP amount is correct.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: FTFY: S/4HANA 2025 should be S/4HANA 2026
entry.content:
We need to fix the S/4HANA version names

S/4HANA carries the version of the year it was released

The problem is, new S/4HANA versions are always released in October/November and carry that year as the version

For example S/4HANA 2025 was released in October 2025

Even the fastest S/4HANA Customers would struggle to get this in to Production before 2026

And that's the problem

The Customer goes live in 2026 with the latest version of S/4HANA....  S/4HANA 2025

And cosmetically if just looks wrong and causes confusion üòû

It looks old before it's even been implemented in Production !

SAP should follow the lead of car manufacturers with the Model Year concept

 
<This part was written by Google AI - AI Overview>
  • Model year (MY): This refers to the model cycle and the specific set of features, trims, and updates for a particular vehicle. For example, a car manufactured in late 2024 could be designated as a 2025 model year (MY2025) because it features the new upgrades for that year

</This part was written by Google AI - AI Overview>

Following this approach, S/4HANA 2025 would be called S/4HANA 2026

And all Customers deploying S/4HANA 2026 during the calendar year 2026 would be able to say to their "Business" that they are rolling out the latest version of S/4HANA which is called S/4HANA 2026

That's it

What do you think ?

Andy.

A good example is the Beta release of AI-powered semantic search which makes finding issues and proposals for process improvement super easy even if you are not yet an SAP expert. entry.title: Re: Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suit
entry.content:
Asynchronous message delivery is a crucial feature of an integration platform, in my opinion. It's an important integration pattern that is often overlooked by developers new to the field of integration, putting the resilience of the integrations and the platform at risk. Cloud Integration let's it up to the developer to implement the integration patterns correctly - which can be seen as an advantage or a weakness (I think it's definitely an advantage, but it requires integration experience). 

So, it's great that SAP built this pattern into the migration tool and offers the Pipeline Concept as a best-practice way to handle asynchronous integration on larger CI systems with many async interfaces that in this way can share the queues.

entry.title: SAP PUPM Business AI: what does it cost to run ONE AI feature ONE time?
entry.content:
SAP made a significant change in its commercial model in July 2025 related to SAP Business AI by introducing the Per User Per Month (PUPM) pricing.

In December 2024 I wrote a blog post on the ‚Äúold ‚Äúcommercial model by analyzing the cost of running a specific CX AI feature.  The old pricing model was pretty much ‚Äúpay for what you use, as you go‚Äù

In this blog post I will do the same cost analysis but now using the PUPM pricing model.

Why did SAP change the pricing model?

Personally, I thought ‚Äúpay for what you use‚Äù sounded very fair and made sense. However, it turned out customers did not like it!!!   The main reason was that it was difficult to forecast the costs upfront. Having certainty of costs upfront is very important for CFOs when making investment decisions and budgets for ‚Äúnext year‚Äù.   It was true; to have a good upfront forecast of costs with the old pricing model a customer would need to estimate how often they would run each of the 100s of SAP Business AI features, each had a different consumption and cost.

 Thus, SAP decided to make it easier for customers and ‚Äújust‚Äù decide on their behalf!   This was done by estimated how much AI each person is expected to use each month in average.  The CFO at the customer then only needs to decide on how many employees would use the AI capabilities.  Much easier.

And if we think about it, it is pretty much the same as all the SAP LOB users.  For example, SAP does not price transaction capacity for ERP Cloud directly, SAP sells users.  Some users will do more activity and transactions than others, and others will do less.  The idea is to keep it simple and assume that in average it will be fair.

Did SAP AI Business AI become more expensive?

With many elements changing from the old to the new pricing model, it is impossible to give a single answer which fits all situations.   However, lets redo the example I did in the previous blog post  of running the CX AI premium embedded feature ‚ÄúWriting a case overview‚Äù,  for which I showed costs 0.049 Euro to run one time in the old pricing model.

Pricing almost the same: 0.054 vs 0.049

In the new PUPM pricing model, the cost is 0.054.  This is 10% increase.  In the big scheme of things this is not dramatic in my opinion.  The ROI is still huge.  Also, the PUPM cost could be as low as 0.034 for customers with a lot of users due to the new tiered pricing.

The ‚Äúdisadvantage‚Äù of the new model is that there is a much higher minimum purchase required to get going (by means of the PUPM package being the minimum to purchase). The ‚Äúadvantage‚Äù is much easier up- front budgeting for the CFO‚Ä¶.

Here are the detailed calculations based on Information from the AI Feature Guide Price List

  • List price of 1 AI Unit is 7 euro
  • One PUPM user per month costs 8 AI units -> 56 euro
  • A user gets 5200 capacity request budget per month
  • Running ‚Äúwriting case summary‚Äù consumes 5 request each time it is used. It means a user can run the AI feature 5200/5 = 1040 times for 56 euro
  • Per run, this comes down to 56 euro / 1040 = 0.054 euro

Running the feature costs 5 request:

One PUPM user costs 8 AI units per month:

Some other elements to keep in mind.

With the new PUPM commercial model there are a couple of elements and dynamics to keep in mind.  Here are the most important in my opinion

Overage: even though SAP estimates how much AI capacity users in average need, there is a fair use policy and if customer goes over, there is an overage fee.  1000 requests overage costs 2 AI units.  In my opinion, it is unlikely that customers will run over, especially if the customer has a lot of AI users.  This is because of the ‚Äúuser pooling‚Äù

User pooling:  If one employee uses more than 5200 request but another user uses less than 5200 requests, it will be averaged out.  This concept is so standardized that SAP does not even track individual request usage (is also good for privacy).  If a customer has 10 AI PUPM users, the users have together 52.000 request capacity per month. At the end of the month, SAP just checks if they all together stayed below 52.000 or not.

Pricing Tiers: as one can see in the table above, there would be significant price reduction if the customer has a lot of PUPM users.  At the end of each month, SAP will calculate how many users the customer had activated during the month and subtract the appropriate AI units from the customer‚Äôs AI unit balance leveraging the AI unit charge per user in the tiering table.

Per month: this is an important (new) concept which differs from ‚Äúnormal‚Äù SAP LOB user pricing.  For normal SAP LOB user pricing the cost & commitment to pay for a user is for a minimum of 12 months.  For PUPM AI user, the minimum is 1 month.  This means that a customer has more flexibility in managing (for example, reducing) the cost of employees not using AI anymore.  This is done by deactivating the user in SAP Cloud Identity Services.  For users not going to use AI moving forwards, make sure to deactivate the user before the end of the current month, then the user will not consume AI units as of next month.

Control of the cost: The customer has itself full control of how many employees has access to AI (by activating and deactivating AI PUPM users).  PUPM users is the main driver for AI Unit consumption.  Thus, in my opinion, customers have the consumption forecast and control pretty much in their own hands via active management of their AI users in SAP Cloud Identity Services.

For more details and always the latest info on SAP Business AI pricing, I recommend to check the SAP Business AI Commercialization deck for partners on a regular basis.

entry.title: Re: Share one number range across 2 systems to facilitate...
entry.content:
Good day @MauricevH 

Thank you for your question.

Please review these references for more details:

Defining Number Ranges, Determine Your Strategy for Number Range Assignment, Maintain Variant Table ID Number Range, Defining Number Ranges and Material Master Number Ranges

In summary, public cloud does not allow you to share material number ranges with ECC or to skip material numbers dynamically. Due to its clean-core approach, it does not provide exits or BadIs to adjust number assignment. This also explains why you cannot implement cross-system synchronised number ranges.

Adhering to the clean-core solution will enable you implement API-based real time validation. ECC checks S4H before accepting a user-entered material number. This is to ensure your 8-digit number remains unique across both systems. Migration Cockpit can still load ECC materials using the same number.

You can, however, alternatively use BTP as central number assignment service to reserve subranges in S4H, or adopt alphanumeric numbers.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Sailing Analytics Goes Open Source
entry.content:
On October 20, 2025, SAP published the source code of the Sailing Analytics solution and its companion apps (Sailing Race Manager, Buoy Pinger, Sail Insight) on GitHub under the Apache 2.0 license. This finally allows all interested parties to contribute to the solution, and optionally even host it themselves. 

This was a logical next step for the project and remains in-line with SAP‚Äôs open source principles described in the SAP Open Source Manifesto. It lays out a vision where open source drives innovation through collaboration and empowers communities through openness. 

What Sailing Analytics Does 

The Sailing Analytics solution helps comment and analyze sailing regattas by combining data from satellite tracking, wind sensors, and decisions by the race committee into live results and analyses. As a cloud solution, it scales from small cost-efficient club-level events to the most visible regattas at the Olympic Summer Games in Tokyo (2020/2021) and Paris (2024), serving hundreds of thousands of concurrent viewers across several regions worldwide. It powers the world's largest sailing tracking database with wind data and proper score boards (https://sapsailing.com). See it in action, live from the upcoming Youth World Championships 2025 in Vilamoura, Portugal taking place December 12-20, 2025, at https://youthworlds2025.sapsailing.com. 

While Sailing Analytics started in the domain of one-design dinghy sailing with a specific focus on Olympic classes, over time it has evolved into many other areas of the complex sport. This includes different handicap formats with support for handicap-based live rankings, and a variety of scoring systems.

 

The solution can be configured to work with different systems for position tracking, wind sensors, external regatta management tools, and official scoring systems. Through its RESTful API it is possible to integrate more external tools and components without a need to change the sources. For tighter integrations, such as tracking systems and administration interfaces, a connector architecture exists that allows developers to extend the solution accordingly.  

Collaboration Models 

With the code base now being released under a permissive open-source license, several new collaboration opportunities have opened.  

In particular: 

  • Sensor technology providers can implement connectivity 
  • Federations, class associations and event hosts can work on new formats and scoring options to be supported 
  • Research institutions can extend the solution for their specific projects and in-depth analysis 
  • Sailing enthusiasts with a background in IT or graphic design can contribute to all layers and aspects of the solution 

Find a Neutral Entity as the New Home 

In the long run, we plan to move this project to a neutral entity, such as a foundation, to collaborate with more individuals and teams to ensure neutral governance. In a foundation, this solution will benefit from established processes for running open-source projects and structures for collaboration that allow interested stakeholders to easily shape the project‚Äôs future together.

 

Join Us for a Technical Webinar 

We plan a one-hour webcast on this subject for the beginning of 2026. There you will learn about the status of the project, the potential going forward, and the concrete ways for you to participate, contribute, and collaborate. Let us know if you are interested either in the comments or by using the email below. Please find more details here. 

For those who can‚Äôt wait, please also use the project‚Äôs discussion board or send an e-mail to support@sapsailing.com to learn more.

entry.title: How to connect with SAP S/4HANA OData Services from SAP APIM? - OAuth 2.0 Based Authentication
entry.content:
Assuming that you have enabled the API Management capability in Integration Suite, I will start with API Provider creation.

1. Create API Proxy - To Generate OAuth Authentication Token

Create an API Proxy with URL type, 

2. Add Policy - To generate OAuth 2.0 Authentication

OAuth v2.0 - To generate the Access Token for the ac

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
       <SupportedGrantTypes>
           <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
       </SupportedGrantTypes>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

 

3. Create API Provider

Connection

TypeOn Premise
HostVirtual Host, as mentioned in Cloud Connector
PortVirtual Port, as mentioned in Cloud Connector
Location IDAs mentioned in Cloud Connector
AuthenticationNONE
Additional Properties:sap-client: XXX

Catalog Service Settings

Path Prefix/sap/opu/odata
Service Collection URL
/IWFND/CATALOGSERVICE;v=2/ServiceCollection
Authentication type
BASIC
Username
SAP's User Name for communication
Password
***

Test connection:

4. Create Key Value Map to store the credentials to S/4HANA

5. Create API Proxy - To call the OData Service from S/4HANA

Select the API Provider, click on Discover to select the API which you wanted to use

Select the API & then click on Create.

 

6. Add Policies to the API Proxy created to call the OData target endpoint on S/4HANA side

Verify API Key - To verify the key which you are going to pass while calling the API.
Where do you get the API? - When you create the Product, and a Subscription, after creating a Subscription in the Developer Hub you will get a Key. That key is to be provided to the Consumer, and this Policy will verify the key sent by the consumer.

 

 <!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey '/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

 

OAuth 2.0 - To verify OAuth Token generated

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <!-- valid values are GenerateAccessToken, GenerateAccessTokenImplicitGrant, GenerateAuthorizationCode ,
    RefreshAccessToken , VerifyAccessToken , InvalidateToken , ValidateToken  -->
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/><SupportedGrantTypes/>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

 

Assign Message - Before setting up basic authentication in a later step, we need to remove the existing Authorization header. I've used the Assign Message policy to achieve this with the following configuration:

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="true" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
    <Remove>   
     	<Headers>      
			<Header name="Authorization"></Header>   
          </Headers>
     </Remove> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Key Value Map Operations - To fetch the credentials saved in the Key Value Mapping

<KeyValueMapOperations mapIdentifier="SAP_S4HANA_Credentials" async="true" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
    <Get assignTo="private.usernameFromKVM" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter>Username</Parameter>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Get assignTo="private.passwordFromKVM" index="1">
        <Key>
            <Parameter>Password</Parameter>
        </Key>
    </Get>
    <Scope>environment</Scope>
</KeyValueMapOperations>

 

Basic Authentication - To pass the credentials fetched in the previous step.

<BasicAuthentication async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Operation>Encode</Operation>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<User ref='private.usernameFromKVM'></User>
	<Password ref='private.passwordFromKVM'></Password>
 	<AssignTo>request.header.Authorization</AssignTo>
</BasicAuthentication>

 

Assign Message - So you get an error as, "{"fault":{"faultstring":"Unsupported Encoding \"br\"","detail":{"errorcode":"protocol.http.UnsupportedEncoding"}}}". 
BR is a data format Brotli which is often defined by backend for webpage loading and not accepted by default. And this Assign Message will help your message reach the target.

 

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
 
	<!-- Sets a new value to the existing parameter -->
	<Set>
		<Headers>
		     <Header name="Accept-Encoding">gzip,deflate</Header>
	     </Headers> 
	</Set>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

 

7. Create Product & Add the both the API Proxies

 

8. Create a Subscription for the Product created

7. It's time to test!

entry.title: Re: Title:"Document Identification When Combining Multipl...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

Below I described my experience in building the reports.

Point 1.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, each business object has its natural key in the VDM CDS views. For example:

Area

Object

Minimal header key in CDS

At item level

Sales (SD)

Sales document

SalesDocument

SalesDocument + SalesDocumentItem

Sales (SD)

Billing document (invoice etc.)

BillingDocument

BillingDocument + BillingDocumentItem

Procurement (MM)

Purchase order

PurchaseOrder

PurchaseOrder + PurchaseOrderItem

Inventory (MM)

Material document

MaterialDocumentYear + MaterialDocument

+ MaterialDocumentItem

Finance (FI)

Journal entry / accounting document

CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocument I_JournalEntry / I_JournalEntryItem

+ AccountingDocumentItem

So:

  • In SD/MM, the document number (SalesDocument, BillingDocument, PurchaseOrder) is unique in the system for that object type and is enough as a technical key.
  • In FI, we always need:
    • CompanyCode
    • FiscalYear
    • AccountingDocument

because the accounting document number alone is not globally unique.

If you build one combined data model where you mix SD/MM/FI documents, it is good practice to add a field that identifies the object type:

SourceObjectType (for example: 'SD_SO', 'SD_BIL', 'MM_PO', 'FI_JE')

SourceDocNumber (SalesDocument / BillingDocument / PurchaseOrder / AccountingDocument)

Point 2.

SD / MM

  • For sales documents (I_SalesDocument):
    • Technically, SalesDocument alone is sufficient as the key.
    • SalesDocumentType is very useful as a reporting dimension, but is not required for uniqueness.
  • For purchase orders (I_PurchaseOrder):
    • PurchaseOrder is sufficient as the key.
    • PurchasingDocumentCategory / PurchasingDocumentType are descriptive/reporting fields.

FI

  • For journal entries (I_JournalEntry, I_JournalEntryItem):
    • AccountingDocument + DocumentType is not sufficient.
    • The minimal robust key is:
  • CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocument
    • JournalEntryType / DocumentType again should be treated as reporting dimensions, not part of the technical key.

Conclusion for the design document:

  • For SD/MM should to use:
    • SalesDocument / BillingDocument / PurchaseOrder (+ item number for item-level reporting).
  • For FI we use:
    • CompanyCode + FiscalYear + AccountingDocument (+ item number for item-level reporting).

Point 3.

The recommended approach in S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition (especially when using the Custom CDS Views app) is:

3.1 Pattern: use the universal journal as a ‚Äúhub‚Äù

  1. Primary Data Source (Cube) in Custom CDS Views:
    • I_JournalEntryItem
      or
    • a GL line item view (I_GLAccountLineItem) depending on your exact requirements.

These views typically provide:

    • CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument, AccountingDocumentItem
    • Logistic reference fields such as:
      • SalesDocument, SalesDocumentItem
      • BillingDocument, BillingDocumentItem
      • PurchaseOrder, PurchaseOrderItem
  1. Associations to Custom CDS View:
    • Associated Data Source: I_SalesDocument / I_SalesDocumentItem
    • Logical join condition:
    • Sales ‚Äì sales documents:
  • I_SalesDocument.SalesDocument = I_JournalEntryItem.SalesDocument
    • Sales ‚Äì billing documents (invoices):
      • Associated Data Source: I_BillingDocument / I_BillingDocumentItem
      • Example join:
  • I_BillingDocument.BillingDocument = I_JournalEntryItem.BillingDocument (+ possibly CompanyCode if available on both sides)
    • Procurement ‚Äì purchase orders:
      • Associated Data Source: I_PurchaseOrder / I_PurchaseOrderItem
      • Join:
  • I_PurchaseOrder.PurchaseOrder = I_JournalEntryItem.PurchaseOrder
  1. On top of this Custom CDS View (type Cube) you create a Custom Analytical Query, where you:
    • SD/MM/FI keys (SalesDocument, BillingDocument, PurchaseOrder, CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument)
    • Your additional fields: SourceObjectType, GlobalDocumentID
    • Organizational dimensions (Sales Organization, Purchasing Organization, Company Code, etc.)
    • Amounts, quantities, margins, etc. from the journal entry items.
    • Expose as dimensions:
    • Expose as measures:

This is the typical ‚Äúcloud-native‚Äù pattern: instead of joining existing reports, you join released VDM/CDS views using their technical keys.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/8573b810511948c8a99c0672abc159aa.html?profile=20496348

 

3.2 Join two separate report

  • one report output based on SD (e.g. I_BillingDocumentItem),
  • another report output based on FI (e.g. I_JournalEntryItem),

then you should use the following keys:

  • Billing <-> FI:
    • CompanyCode
    • FiscalYear
    • AccountingDocument
    • CompanyCode
    • FiscalYear
    • AccountingDocument
    • SD billing side (billing CDS view):
    • FI side (journal entry CDS view):
    • Join on these three fields.
  • Sales order <-> FI:
    • Either via the chain:
      SalesDocument ‚Üí BillingDocument ‚Üí (CompanyCode, FiscalYear, AccountingDocument)
    • Or directly if SalesDocument is available in the journal entry item view in your release.
  • Purchase order ‚Üî FI:
    • Use PurchaseOrder (and optionally PurchaseOrderItem) on both sides.

Point 4.

4.1 Standard Fiori apps

  • A standard Fiori app may not display all technical key fields on the UI.
  • This does not mean the fields do not exist ‚Äì they are usually present in the underlying VDM/ CDS view.
  • When building your own reporting, you work with the released CDS views, not with what is visible on a particular Fiori UI.

4.2 Custom CDS Views ‚Äì what can limit you

  • You can only use released CDS views
  • Not all internal technical fields are exposed.
  • Frequently, logistic reference keys are available only at item level (for example SalesDocument at journal entry item level), so:
    • It is often better to build your cube at item level (I_JournalEntryItem, I_BillingDocumentItem, I_PurchaseOrderItem),
    • and then aggregate in the query/analytic layer,
    • instead of trying to do everything purely at header level.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/0bde695751505c08e10000000a441470.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F2170')/S35

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Optimizing Business Processes and Enterprise Architecture with the Integrated Toolchain
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs fast-moving digital landscape, organizations need more than isolated tools, they need a seamless, connected ecosystem that enables process transparency, architectural coherence, and efficient execution. That‚Äôs why the SAP Enterprise Support team is excited to introduce a new e-learning course: Optimizing Business Processes and Enterprise Architecture with the Integrated Toolchain.

This learning experience is part of the Business Transformation Management Value Map and supports your journey with curated knowledge, hands-on guidance, and practical demonstrations that help you get the most value from the SAP Signavio, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM integration.

Why the Integrated Toolchain Matters

SAP‚Äôs Integrated Toolchain is a cornerstone of the RISE with SAP Methodology, designed to bring together the strengths of SAP Signavio, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM into one powerful end-to-end ecosystem. By orchestrating these solutions, the toolchain strengthens collaboration between business and IT, speeds up process synchronization, and ensures smoother transitions from planning to execution.

The toolchain connects:

  • SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub

  • SAP Signavio Process Intelligence

  • SAP LeanIX

  • SAP Cloud ALM

Together, they create a consistent, scalable approach to business transformation ‚Äî enabling process improvements that align with strategic goals and deliver measurable results.

A Practical Walkthrough for End Users

The new e-learning course focuses on helping architects, practitioners, and team members who work with the toolchain after it has been configured. It delivers:

  • A clear, practical walkthrough of each tool from an end-user perspective

  • Step-by-step demonstrations showing how the tools connect and interact

  • Guidance on navigating each component efficiently

Whether you‚Äôre analyzing business processes, mapping enterprise architecture, or executing transformation tasks, this course helps you understand exactly how to work effectively within the integrated environment.

To access the E-Learning, you must complete a one-time registration in SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, using your S-User ID.
Click here for the step-by-step registration guide

About the author:  

Rachel is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in‚ÄØBusiness Transformation Management. With‚ÄØ7 years of experience at SAP and a background spanning roles in‚ÄØ Customer Service and Delivery Consulting. Rachel is passionate about helping customers succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings. 

üí° Have questions or feedback around this content? Don‚Äôt hesitate to comment down below or contact‚ÄØ@RachelMcDonagh.

entry.title: Display Departments in custom field based upon Head of Department position

At Department object, we maintain a custom field called "Head of Department Position".  A position can be Head of Department for single department or multiple departments.

We maintain this field "Head of Department Position" at Position object also. We have a requirement, where a custom field in Position Object should display all departments (concatenated by , or -) for which "Head of Department Position" is same.

For Example: For Dept1, Dept2 and Dept3, HOD is "Head of Department Position".
For Position1, HOD is "Head of Department Position", then custom field in Position1 should display value as Dept1, Dept2, Dept3.
